advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT SEPT. 1981</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> STICKER</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a promotional adhesive sticker of the RC 700 Piccolo... What a visionary thought!</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #1 (1977)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first Apple II advert.<br><br> Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Clear the kitchen table. Bring in the color TV. Plug in your new Apple ll and connect any standard cassette recorder / player. Now, you're ready for an evening of discovery in the new world of personal computers.<br> Only Apple ll makes it that easy. At $1298, it includes video graphics in 15 colors, 8KB ROM and 4KB RAM... It's the first personal computer with a fast version of BASIC permanently stored in ROM...<br><br> Apple ll is also available in board-only form to the do-it-yourself hobbyist. Has all of the features of the Apple ll system but does not include case, keyboard, power supply or game paddles. $598</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"At the fingertip of the mouse..." <br><br> "... 16/32 bits technology"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (APRIL 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (DEC. 1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to David Wilson for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROTOTYPE SOFTWARE</strong></font><br><blockquote>This picture from an early advert published in january 1983 is very interesting (the TO-7 was just released then). The text below it said "Hours of entertainment...". But when you look more carefully at the software boxes you realise that they are fake! Only the two extreme boxes are real, but still shows the same game title "3-D TIC-TAC TOE"! So there is only one game presented here! The photograph was surely taken at an early development stage... <br><br> Even the name of the computer written on top of the boxes: "TOM 7" (Tele Ordinateur Multimedia?) seems to be an early name for the TO-7... <br><br> Hours of entertainment they said...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JACQUARD BROCHURE #2 </strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert from Byte magazine (january 1977) said : <br><br> ...It gets its speed and power from a selected version of the new Z80 microprocessor that can operate at a 4 Mhz. clock rate (The Z-1 also lets you switch to 2 Mhz. to be compatible with older systems)...<br> ...The Z-1 offers you all kinds of peripherals and softwares. It uses the standard ''S100'' bus supported by over a dozen manufacturers. And all Cromemco peripherals (PROM memory and programmer, Ram memory, analog I/O, color TV interface, etc) just plug into the Z1's sockets...<br> ... The Z-1 comes completely assembled ans tested. It's a quality, commercial grade microcomputer. It is not available as a kit.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.K. AD. 1989</strong></font><br><blockquote>Special 520-STFM bundle advert.<br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> There's no catch. We're giving you the Atari 520 STFM and £500 worth of great software titles for just £399.99.<br> The twenty-three super titles include some of the greatest games and three excellent programs which introduce you to the BASIC programming language, computer-created music and the more popular computer applications such as word processing and spreadsheets...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN AD #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Welcome in the world of the "clean"-computers"<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.sharpmz.org</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>A pretty secretary, a clean office with nice colours, and a computer working without any printer, cables, disks... Does it really sound realistic to you ?!</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPARISON CHART</strong></font><br><blockquote>This document compares the different Panasonic systems of the serie<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ARGENTINIAN ADVERT </strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.speccy.org/czarg/" target="_blank">CZARG</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NICE AD (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>As computing was a serious and professional subject, the humorus adverts was rare in 1983.<br> This one said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> When I told my Dad about NEC TREK, NEC's new personal computer, he wanted one right away.<br><br> I told him it has 10 programmable function keys; high powered graphic capabilities, powerful Microsoft BASIC included, and a 8-octave programmable musical tone generator.<br><br> He said it has lot of 'fun games'. <br><br> I told him how its memory storage can interface with cassette diskette or cartridge, and how it has a wide variety of of sophisticated software available - important things like financial management package...<br><br> He just challenged me to a game of Protector.<br><br> That's my Dad. I love him, but sometimes I wish he could understand how a kid feels.</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE #5</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (DEC. 1986)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SOL PRICE LIST</strong></font><br><blockquote><b><u>Sol Systems price list (january 1977)</u></b> <br><br> (K) = Kit (A) = Assembled<br><br> <b>Sol Terminal Computers<br> </b>SOL-PC Single board (K) <b> $475</b><br> SOL-10 (K) <b> $795</b><br> SOL-20 (K) <b> $995</b> <br><br> <b>Memory Modules</b> <br> PROM Resident Assembly Language (A) <b>$425</b><br> Interpretive Simulator (PROM option) (A) <b>$95</b><br> Text Editing (PROM option) (A) <b>$95</b><br> Erasable PROM module (K) <b>$65 </b>(A) <b>$89</b> <br> 4 Kb. low power static Ram (K) <b> $159</b> (A) <b> $195</b><br> 8 Kb. low power static Ram (K) <b>$295</b> (A) <b>$375</b><br> 16 Kb. Dynamic Ram (A) <b>$529</b> <br><br> <b>Interface Modules</b><br> Parallel / Serial I/O Module (K) <b>$149</b> (A) <b>$199</b><br> System cassette interface (K) <b>$87 </b> (A) <b>$119</b><br> Video Display Module (K) <b>$199 </b> (A) <b>$295</b><br> <br> <b>Mass Storage System</b><br> Helios II Disk system (K) <b>$1895</b> (A) <b>$2295</b><br><br> <b>Software<br> </b>(C) = Cassette (P) = Paper tape<br> Basic 5 (P) <b>$19.95</b><br> 8K Basic (C) <b>$29</b> (P) <b>$37</b><br> New 8080 Focal (C) <b>$14.50</b> <br> Trek 80 Video game (C) <b>$9.50</b> (P) <b>$14.50</b><br> GamePack 1 (C) <b>$9.50</b> (P) <b>$14.50</b><br> MathPack Video calculator (C) <b>$14.50</b> (P) <b>$19.50</b><br> Assembler (C) <b>$14.50</b> (P) <b>$19.50</b><br> ALS 8 (C) <b>$35</b> (P) <b>$45</b> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #4</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD. JUNE 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.description:
Info needed about this obscure CP/M computer!
Monroe - a subsidary of Litton Inc. - used to produce and sell calculators for years from 1912.
Very little is known about this CP/M system. To use the floppies you had to type in OPEN FPY0:
____________
Thanks to Jan S?derberg for the pictures.
computer.keyboard: Full stroke keyboard with function keys and numeric keypad. 93 keys.
computer.name: OC-8880
computer.ports: External disk drive, expansion bus, composite video output (monochrome), AUX serial I/O, COMM I/O, parallel printer interface

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> OC 8880</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://w1.184.telia.com/~u18407217/" target="_blank">Jan Soderberg</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>Notice the on/off switch on the side of the case.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://w1.184.telia.com/~u18407217/" target="_blank">Jan Soderberg</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://w1.184.telia.com/~u18407217/" target="_blank">Jan Soderberg</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
